Introduction

Fault Injector

A Python package for injecting various faults into numeric time-series or sensor data.

This package allows simulation of real-world sensor anomalies including drift, offset, noise, missing data, and stuck readings. Faults can be applied over a specified range of indices.

Supported Fault Types & Mathematical Background

  1. Drift

    Linear change over time:

    \[y_i = x_i + (i - s) \cdot \text{drift_rate}, \quad i \in [s, e)\]

    • \(\text{drift_rate}\) can be provided or randomly generated as \(\text{drift_rate} \sim U(0, 0.0001) \cdot d \cdot \bar{x}\)

    • \(d\) = fault direction (+1 increasing, -1 decreasing)

    • \(\bar{x}\) = mean of original values

  2. Offset

    Constant bias added to the values:

    \[y_i = x_i + \text{offset_value}, \quad i \in [s, e)\]

    • \(\text{offset_value} = \bar{x} \cdot \text{offset_rate}\)

  3. Gaussian Noise

    Random noise with normal distribution:

    \[y_i = x_i + \epsilon_i, \quad \epsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2), \quad i \in [s, e)\]

    • Defaults: \(\mu = 0\), \(\sigma = \text{std}(x[s:e])\)

  4. Uniform Noise

    Random noise with uniform distribution:

    \[y_i = x_i + \epsilon_i, \quad \epsilon_i \sim U(a, b), \quad i \in [s, e)\]

    • Defaults: \(a = -\text{std}(x[s:e]), b = \text{std}(x[s:e])\)

  5. NaN

    Replace values with missing data:

    \[\begin{split}y_i = \begin{cases} \text{NaN}, & i \in [s, e) \\ x_i, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

  6. Stuck Value

    Replace values with a constant:

    \[\begin{split}y_i = \begin{cases} c, & i \in [s, e) \\ x_i, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

    • \(c\) can be specified or randomly generated as \(c = \bar{x} + d \cdot U(0.01, 0.1) \cdot \bar{x}\)

Notes

  • Faults are applied over the range [start, stop).

  • The class preserves the original values for comparison.

  • Useful for testing robustness of sensor data processing algorithms, anomaly detection, and fault-tolerant systems.

Related Paper

For more details, see The Impact of Sensor Faults on Condition Monitoring of a Hydraulic Actuator.
